case_id: Stree Atyachar Virodhi Parishad v. Dilip Nathumal Chordiya (1989)
facts: The Stree Atyachar Virodhi Parishad (Appellant), a registered public society dedicated to assisting women subjected to atrocities, filed a criminal complaint.

The complaint was filed before the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Pune, against Dilip Nathumal Chordiya (Respondent No. 1), his parents (Respondents Nos. 2 & 3), his married sister (Respondent No. 4), and his distant relatives (uncle and cousins - Respondents Nos. 5, 6, & 7).
The complaint alleged that Chanda, wife of Dilip Chordiya, was subjected to physical and mental torture by the respondents due to dissatisfaction with dowry.
Specific allegations included demands for Rs. 50,000, beatings, starvation, and threats, leading Chanda to leave the matrimonial home and stay with her parents.
The Magistrate took cognizance of the complaint and issued process against all accused under Section 498A IPC.
The Respondents filed an application under Section 482 CrPC before the Bombay High Court seeking to quash the proceedings.

The High Court quashed the proceedings on two main grounds: (i) The Appellant Parishad, being a third party, had no *locus standi* to file the complaint under Section 498A IPC, as Section 198A CrPC specifies who can complain for this offense. (ii) The allegations against the distant relatives (Respondents 4-7) were vague and did not constitute an offense under Section 498A IPC, as they were not 'relatives' within the meaning intended by the section.
The Stree Atyachar Virodhi Parishad appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court.
The victim, Chanda, also filed an affidavit before the Supreme Court supporting the Parishad's complaint and confirming the allegations.
The State of Maharashtra supported the Appellant Parishad's stance.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The Appellant Parishad, as a public-spirited organization, has the locus standi to initiate criminal proceedings for a cognizable offense like Section 498A IPC.
precedents: A. R. Antulay v. Ramdas Sriniwas Nayak (1984) 2 SCC 500: Anyone can set the criminal law in motion unless there is a specific legal bar.
Vishwanath v. State of U.P. (1960) AIR 67 (SC): Reinforces the general principle that absence of a complaint by the victim is not fatal for cognizable offenses.
Sheo Nandan Paswan v. State of Bihar (1987) 1 SCC 288: Discusses locus standi in criminal law, emphasizing public interest in prosecution.
elements: General rule under CrPC allows anyone to file information about cognizable offenses.
Section 198A CrPC provides an enabling provision for certain persons to file a complaint, but does not bar others from initiating proceedings for a cognizable offense.

counter_arguments.loophole: Section 198A CrPC specifically lists persons who can file a complaint for Section 498A IPC, implying a restriction on third parties.
supporting_precedents: G. Narasimhan v. T. V. Chokkappa (1972) 2 SCC 680: Discusses specific bars under CrPC (like S. 199 for defamation) limiting who can complain.
JT 1988 (4) SC 108 (Implied comparison to specific bars, although no direct precedent cited by defense on 198A being *restrictive* rather than *enabling*).
Insufficient data: Specific precedents arguing S.198A CrPC is exhaustive/restrictive were not extensively cited or relied upon by the High Court or defense in the SC judgment.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The term 'relative' in Section 498A IPC should be interpreted broadly to include distant relatives if they participated in the cruelty, and the High Court erred in quashing the complaint prematurely without trial.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: Quashing power under S. 482 CrPC should be used sparingly, especially when allegations prima facie disclose an offense.
Nagawwa v. Veeranna Shivalingappa Konjalgi (1976) 3 SCC 736: Magistrate's order issuing process should not be interfered with lightly if based on prima facie case.
U. Suvetha v. State (2009) 6 SCC 757: Discusses interpretation of 'relative' in dowry cases (though post-dates this case, reflects principle).
elements: The complaint contains specific allegations against all respondents, including distant relatives.
Whether the allegations constitute cruelty under S. 498A is a matter for trial.
Statutory interpretation should favour the object of the legislation (preventing cruelty against women).
The High Court should not have conducted a mini-trial based on affidavits.

counter_arguments.loophole: Allegations against distant relatives (Respondents 4-7) were vague and lacked specific details of time, place, and nature of cruelty attributed to each.
supporting_precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: One ground for quashing is if allegations are so absurd or inherently improbable.
Madhavrao Jiwajirao Scindia v. Sambhajirao Chandrojirao Angre (1988) 1 SCC 692: Proceedings can be quashed if allegations do not constitute the offence alleged.
Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2015) 6 SCC 477: Stresses need for specific allegations against each accused in dowry/cruelty cases.

defense_arguments.argument: The Appellant Parishad lacks locus standi to file the complaint. Section 198A CrPC creates a specific mechanism and lists the only persons (victim, specified relatives, or public servant with state govt sanction) competent to file a complaint for an offense under Section 498A IPC.
edge_cases: Distinction between filing FIR for cognizable offense (anyone) vs. filing a formal complaint before Magistrate under specific procedural bars/requirements.
Analogy to Section 199 CrPC (defamation) where only the aggrieved person can complain.
precedents: G. Narasimhan v. T. V. Chokkappa (1972) 2 SCC 680: Where CrPC specifies who can complain for certain offenses, that procedure must be followed.
Insufficient data: Specific precedents directly interpreting S. 198A CrPC as a complete bar were not explicitly relied upon in the SC judgment text, though this was the core of the HC reasoning.
Insufficient data: Lack of direct precedent cited in the judgment supporting the claim that S.198A overrides the general principle for cognizable offences.

defense_arguments.argument: The term 'relative' in Section 498A IPC refers only to relatives connected by blood, marriage, or adoption who ordinarily reside with the husband or have significant interaction impacting the wife's life in the matrimonial home. Distant relatives like uncles and cousins (Respondents 5-7) and even a married sister living separately (Respondent 4) are not covered.
edge_cases: Meaning of 'relative' in social vs legal context.
Potential for misuse of S. 498A by roping in distant family members.
precedents: Insufficient data: No specific precedents defining 'relative' under 498A were cited by the defense as per the SC judgment text.
State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: Can be cited contextually for the principle that vexatious implication of entire families should be prevented via S. 482 power.
Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207: While later, discusses the trend of over-implication of relatives (illustrates the concern).

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly exercised its power under Section 482 CrPC to quash the proceedings as the allegations were vague, particularly against Respondents 4-7, and allowing the trial would be an abuse of process.
edge_cases: Inherent power of High Court to prevent abuse of process.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335: Sets out guidelines for quashing FIR/complaint.
Madhavrao Jiwajirao Scindia v. Sambhajirao Chandrojirao Angre (1988) 1 SCC 692: Quashing appropriate if complaint doesn't disclose essential ingredients of offense.
Pepsi Foods Ltd. v. Special Judicial Magistrate (1998) 5 SCC 749: High Court can quash proceedings to prevent manifest injustice or abuse of process.

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. The judgment of the High Court was set aside, and the order of the Magistrate issuing process was restored. The Magistrate was directed to proceed with the trial in accordance with law.
reasoning: Section 498A IPC makes cruelty by husband or relatives a cognizable offense. The general principle of criminal law is that anyone who is aware of the commission of a cognizable offense can set the law in motion.

Section 198A CrPC, introduced alongside Section 498A IPC, provides an additional avenue for the victim or specific relatives/persons to file a complaint. It is an enabling provision, not a restrictive one. It does not override the general rule that allows anyone to report a cognizable offense to the police or file a complaint before a Magistrate.
The High Court erred in treating Section 198A CrPC as a bar analogous to Section 198 or 199 CrPC, which explicitly restrict locus standi for specific offenses like defamation.

The term 'relative' in Section 498A IPC should not be given a restricted meaning. Whether a person is a 'relative' who subjected the woman to cruelty is a matter of evidence to be determined during trial. The High Court should not have quashed the complaint against distant relatives at the preliminary stage based on a narrow interpretation.

The allegations in the complaint, supported by the victim's affidavit, prima facie disclosed an offense under Section 498A IPC against all respondents. The High Court was not justified in embarking upon an inquiry into the merits or reliability of the allegations at the stage of Section 482 CrPC.
Quashing the proceedings prematurely denied the complainant the opportunity to establish the case through evidence at trial.
cited_cases: A. R. Antulay v. Ramdas Sriniwas Nayak (1984) 2 SCC 500
Vishwanath v. State of U.P. (1960) AIR 67 (SC) (Mentioned principle, not explicitly cited)
G. Narasimhan v. T. V. Chokkappa (1972) 2 SCC 680 (Distinguished)
State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992) Supp (1) SCC 335 (Cited principles on quashing, though judgment predates it, the principles were established)
